conversations.description: User signs up, selects interests like AI, climate, and sports; the LLM confirms choices and fetches initial RSS feeds.
Subscriber asks to add a new technology blog RSS URL; the assistant validates, fetches recent items, and updates the feed list.
User queries why a particular article was ranked high; the LLM explains relevance based on keyword matching in the profile.
Subscriber wants a weekend digest focusing only on entertainment news; the assistant adjusts the ranking filter for that day.
User reports an article summary is off‑topic; the LLM revises the summary and updates the user profile to deprioritize that topic.
Subscriber asks for a condensed version of a long investigative piece; the assistant extracts content, summarizes in three sentences, and emails it.
User wants to pause the daily email for a vacation week; the LLM records the pause and resumes automatically after the dates.
Subscriber requests a “deep‑dive” on renewable energy trends; the assistant fetches multiple sources, merges summaries, and sends a special brief.
User asks to remove politics from the digest; the LLM updates the interest profile to exclude political keywords.
Subscriber receives the daily email and clicks a link; the assistant logs the click to improve future relevance scoring.
User asks for a summary of the top three business headlines in under 60 seconds; the LLM provides concise spoken‑style text.
Subscriber wants to experiment with a “random surprise” article each day; the assistant adds a randomization step to ranking.
User asks why a normally ignored source appeared this morning; the LLM explains a trending keyword triggered higher relevance.
Subscriber wants a separate digest for a colleague using the same interests but different tone; the LLM creates a custom email style.
User requests a weekly summary of all articles about blockchain they missed; the assistant aggregates and sends a weekend roundup.
Subscriber asks to integrate a corporate intranet RSS feed; the assistant validates access and merges internal news with external sources.
User wishes to change email delivery time from 7 am to 9 am; the LLM updates the schedule and confirms the new time.
Subscriber asks for an “expert perspective” on a trending health study; the assistant pulls academic sources and adds a concise expert note.
User wants to test a new interest keyword ‘quantum computing’; the LLM adds it temporarily and shows the next day’s ranking.
Subscriber reports a broken link in the digest; the assistant verifies and replaces it with an alternative source.
User asks for a visual summary – a markdown table of headlines, sources, and brief scores; the assistant formats and emails it.
Subscriber wants to downgrade from daily to three‑times‑a‑week emails; the LLM adjusts frequency and confirms the next send dates.
User requests to see the raw RSS feed entries before summarization; the assistant returns a list of titles and URLs.
Subscriber asks for a sentiment analysis of the day’s political news; the LLM tags each summary with a positive/negative tone.
User asks to prioritize local news from a city‑specific RSS feed; the assistant raises its ranking weight for that source.
Subscriber wants the digest in plain‑text instead of markdown; the LLM reformats the email body accordingly.
User asks for a “quick read” mode limiting each summary to one sentence; the LLM truncates summaries before ranking.
Subscriber wonders why a repeated article appears; the assistant explains a new update to the original story.
User wants to export their interest profile as a JSON file; the LLM generates the file and provides a download link.
Subscriber asks to add a podcast RSS feed and include episode summaries in the digest.
User requests a special edition digest for a major event like the Olympics, focusing on related sports and cultural stories.
Subscriber asks the assistant to flag any article containing “fake news” warnings and omit them from the email.
User wants to test an AI‑generated headline for an article, comparing it to the original title.
Subscriber asks the LLM to recommend new RSS sources based on their current interests.
User wants to set a daily word‑limit for the entire digest; the assistant trims summaries to stay under the cap.
Subscriber asks for a bilingual digest, with each summary presented in English and Spanish.
User wants to see a heatmap of topic coverage over the past month; the assistant produces a markdown table with counts.
Subscriber asks the assistant to suppress all articles from a specific domain for the next two weeks.
User wants a “morning briefing” podcast version; the LLM generates a short audio script from the top summaries.
Subscriber requests an alert if any article mentions a specific stock ticker, with immediate email notification.
User asks for a historical comparison: today’s tech headlines vs. the same day last year.
Subscriber wants to add a personal note at the top of the email; the LLM includes the user’s custom greeting.
User asks the assistant to evaluate the credibility of each source and attach a rating badge.
Subscriber wants the digest to be sent as a PDF attachment instead of inline markdown.
User asks for a “no‑click” version where each summary includes the full article text for offline reading.
Subscriber inquires about the most frequently occurring keywords across the week’s curated articles.
User wants to merge two separate interest profiles into a single digest for a shared household email.
Subscriber asks to schedule a one‑off digests for a future date, like a holiday special.
User wants to see a list of articles that were filtered out due to low relevance, for transparency.
Subscriber asks the LLM to add a short “Did you know?” fact related to one of the top articles.
User wants to change the email sender name to a custom brand name.
Subscriber asks for a concise list of upcoming events extracted from the top news stories.
User wants the digest to highlight any article that contains a discount or promotional code.
Subscriber requests the assistant to annotate each summary with estimated reading time.
User asks for a “night mode” version of the email with a dark‑theme markdown style.
